Award.AwardTitle: TC: Medium: Collaborative Research: Experience-Based Access Management (EBAM) for Hospital Information Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Insufficient attention has been given to enterprise Identity and Access Management (IAM) as a process that needs to be carried out on a continuing basis in the presence of change and evolution. In particular, there is little formal support for how IAM can exploit experience the enterprise collects over time. This project is developing a lifecycle model of IAM called Experience Based Access Management (EBAM) that provides a set of models, techniques, and tools to reconcile differences between the "ideal" access model, as judged by high-level enterprise, professional, and legal standards, and the "enforced" access control, specific to the operational IAM system. The principal component of an EBAM support system is an "expected" access model that is used to represent differences between the ideal and enforced models based on information collected from access logs and other operational information. The project is developing and validating an approach to the expected model based on using probabilistic information to inform the design of access rules. The project focuses on EBAM for hospital information systems since these are an especially important class of enterprise systems that present diverse and interesting challenges but also provide potential insight into similar issues in other types of enterprise IAM systems. The team consists of specialists in cyber security, biomedical informatics, and a physician who serves as chief medical information officer within a major hospital system. The project will demonstrate how analysis of clinical experience can address gaps between ideal and enforced access control models in a representative hospital.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaboration between the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Northwestern University/Northwestern Memorial Hospital (NMH) and Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VMUC) with many of the methods inspired by and validated by actual log data from NMH and VUMC.

Private data is now often stored in electronic systems. This digital format provides many benefits including in a healthcare context where doctors can access patient charts remotely and contribute to a patient's care. With this electronic storage, however, inappropriate access to the data becomes a potentially greater risk. Inappropriate accesses to a chart may occur when users outside an organization break in through external security systems. Additionally, inappropriate accesses may occur when an employee accesses information to which he is not entitled. The focus of this project was to model how users typically access charts in medical centers with an eye to identifying potentially unusual access patterns. Further, by assembling a comprehensive lists of chart accesses, this project was designed to reveal insights about the chart users including patterns of accesses among similar users and among similar patient types and to inform organizations regarding internal workflow.  

Insights from this project revealed a great deal regarding nuances of protecting and maintaining confidential information. These insights were published in several articles. For example, it is possible to model the effects of stopping users before charts are accessed, which may delay appropriate users, too, versus waiting until an after the fact analysis occurs to identify potentially inappropriate chart users. It is also possible to group users based on the types of medical problems mentioned in the charts they access. Further, it is then possible to compare groups of charts across organizations based on the types of medical problems described. By grouping users and charts in different ways, it becomes possible to predict whether a particular user is likely to access a particular chart. It was also possible to analyze sequences of access to charts to identify patterns in the sequences and determine when a random user was introduced somewhere into the sequence. Additionally, it was possible to infer potential new sub-specialties of users based on a narrow spectrum of patient types with which they interacted.

In conclusion, this research project enabled the science of protecting patient privacy to advance. This science includes new modeling and analytic approaches for chart access patterns and increased understanding regarding how charts are typically accessed within busy medical centers.
